questions.text: Which of these is not a grievous hurt?
questions.correct_answer: C. Abrasion over cheek

questions.text: Two people had a fight in the morning. Later that evening, one of them was found dead. The clothes of the other person had some blood stains, and after testing, it was found that the blood belonged to the person who died. This is what type of evidence?
questions.correct_answer: B. Circumstantial Evidence

questions.text: In a case of death due to alleged poisoning, the prosecution presents a toxicology expert who testifies that the victim’s body had toxic substance based on the analysis of the stomach contents. The defense argues that the expert’s testimony should be inadmissible as toxicology expert neither examined the victim while he was alive, nor he conducted the autopsy himself. Which of the below is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The toxicology expert’s testimony is inadmissible because they did not have first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition at the time of death.

options.label: B
options.text: The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: The forensic expert’s testimony is admissible only if it can be corroborated by a common witness who had first-hand knowledge of the victim’s condition.

questions.correct_answer: B. The toxicology testimony is admissible as it is based on expert opinion, not on first-hand knowledge.

questions.text: In a criminal trial, the prosecution calls a witness who initially agrees to testify but then becomes evasive and refuses to cooperate, contradicting prior statements. The prosecutor seeks permission to ask leading questions during examination-in-chief. Under what circumstance can this be allowed?

options.label: A
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case.

options.label: B
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

options.label: C
options.text: A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime.

questions.correct_answer: B. A leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man married for 5 years was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done?
questions.correct_answer: A. Police inquest

questions.text: Which of the following is true in context of Inquest in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests

options.label: B
options.text: Investigating police officer can go to witness, but cannot summon them to police station

options.label: C
options.text: Doctor can refuse to do autopsy if he thinks probable cause of death is natural

options.label: D
options.text: Doctor has to handover the dead body to relatives after the postmortem

questions.correct_answer: A. The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The Executive magistrate need to be informed of all types of inquests

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid reason for conducting an in-camera trial in a rape case under Indian law?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the possibility of the accused being publicly humiliated during the trial

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a secure environment for the victim by not allowing accused to be present during the trial

questions.correct_answer: A. To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) To ensure that the victim's dignity is preserved during the trial.

questions.text: A neurosurgeon was referred a trauma patient by a primary care physician. The neurosurgeon after treating the patients, sends the appreciation letter to the primary care physician mentioning how timely referral helped him to save the life of the patient. This practice is called?
questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, Mr. Sharma without any relevant past medical history, visits Dr Singh in a hospital with abdominal discomfort. Dr. Singh makes a diagnosis of gastritis and prescribes antacids. However, a few hours later, Mr. Sharma collapses at home and is rushed back to the emergency, where he is found to have a MI, and treated and stabilized accordingly. Mr. Sharma's family files a civil lawsuit against Dr. Singh and the hospital, claiming that there was medical negligence in diagnosing as Dr Singh did not order ECG and cardiac tests. Who bears the onus of proof in this medical negligence case?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. Singh, because he must prove that his clinical decision was based on standard medical practice.

options.label: C
options.text: The hospital, because it is the employer and responsible for the actions of its staff under vicarious liability.

options.label: D
options.text: Shared between the patient's family and the hospital, as both need to provide evidence to support or refute the claim.

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent an appendectomy. Post-surgery, she experienced severe abdominal pain and subsequent investigations revealed a surgical sponge left inside her abdomen. The woman has filed a lawsuit against the operating surgeon. In this case, which legal principle suggests that the burden of proof for demonstrating the absence of negligence rests with the doctor?
questions.correct_answer: B. Res ipsa loquitor

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes a routine cataract surgery in his right eye. After the surgery, he experiences significant and sudden vision loss in the operated eye. Further investigation reveals that the surgeon mistakenly operated on the wrong eye. The patient files a civil lawsuit against the surgeon for medical negligence. In this case, which of the following is correct regarding the burden of proof?

options.label: A
options.text: Burden of proof lies on patient to prove that surgeon was negligent in operating on wrong eye.

options.label: B
options.text: Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Burden of proof lies on both patient and surgeon as it is a case of contributory negligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Burden of proof lies on patient to prove that surgeon’s actions directly led to the vision loss.

questions.correct_answer: B. Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Burden of proof lies on surgeon to prove that operating on wrong eye was not due to negligence.

questions.text: Medical etiquette refers to:

options.label: A
options.text: The legal obligations and contracts between doctors

options.label: B
options.text: The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors

options.label: C
options.text: The moral principles that guide doctor-patient interactions

questions.correct_answer: B. The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The respectful behavior and professional courtesy between doctors

questions.text: A patient undergoes a routine abdominal surgery, but post-operation, a surgical instrument is discovered inside the patient’s body. The patient files a lawsuit citing medical negligence. Which of the following statements regarding the application of the doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitur is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Res Ipsa Loquitur applies because retained instrument typically does not occur without someone's negligence, allowing the patient to establish a presumption of negligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Burden of proof shifts to the surgeon to demonstrate that all reasonable care was taken and that the instrument’s retention may have occurred despite following standard procedures.

options.label: C
options.text: Res Ipsa Loquitur permits the patient to avoid proving specific negligence, but the doctor is automatically deemed liable under this doctrine, with no further defense possible.

options.label: D
options.text: For Res Ipsa Loquitur to be invoked, the cause of the injury must have been within the exclusive control of the surgeon or their team at the time of the surgery.

questions.correct_answer: C. Res Ipsa Loquitur permits the patient to avoid proving specific negligence, but the doctor is automatically deemed liable under this doctrine, with no further defense possible.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Res Ipsa Loquitur permits the patient to avoid proving specific negligence, but the doctor is automatically deemed liable under this doctrine, with no further defense possible.

questions.text: A patient, Mr. X, undergoes surgery for a hernia at a hospital. During the procedure, the surgeon, Dr. Y, inadvertently makes a small incision that causes internal bleeding. Dr. Y admits that this mistake was a result of his negligence during the surgery. However, Dr. Y argues that the patient, Mr. X, contributed to the injury as he failed to follow the post-operative care instructions, such as refraining from heavy lifting, which led to complications. Who has the onus to prove that the patient was also negligent?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient, because they must prove that their actions did not contribute to the injury.

options.label: B
options.text: The doctor, because they admitted to negligence and must prove that the patient's actions contributed to the injury.

options.label: C
options.text: The court, because it must determine the extent of both parties' negligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Patient has the onus to prove that he was not negligent and doctor has the onus to prove that patient was negligent

questions.correct_answer: B. The doctor, because they admitted to negligence and must prove that the patient's actions contributed to the injury.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery for appendicitis at a hospital. The surgeon was drunk at that time. The patient was discharged the next day. Later, after a few days, the patient died due to sepsis. An autopsy revealed a surgical sponge in the abdomen. A charge of criminal negligence is made against the doctor, who admits that this mistake was a result of his negligence during the surgery. However, surgeon argues that the patient, contributed to the injury as he did not report to the hospital when he developed symptoms of sepsis. Had he come in time, he would have been saved. Who has the onus to prove that the patient was also negligent?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient, because they must prove that their actions did not contribute to the injury.

options.label: B
options.text: The doctor, because they admitted to negligence and must prove that the patient's actions contributed to the injury.

options.label: C
options.text: The court, because it must determine the extent of both parties' negligence.

options.label: D
options.text: The onus to proving the negligence of the patient is not applicable in this case.

questions.correct_answer: D. The onus to proving the negligence of the patient is not applicable in this case.

questions.text: A 7-year child is likely to have following set of permanent Molars and permanent premolars:
questions.correct_answer: B. 4 permanent molar, 0 permanent premolars

questions.text: First permanent teeth to erupt in socket of temporary teeth?
questions.correct_answer: B. Permanent Central Incisor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the fingerprints is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Left and right hand prints of an individual are identical; only the orientation of the hand changes.

options.label: B
options.text: Fingerprints are mostly full formed before birth, but keeps undergoing further refinement by adolescence, so not much helpful in childhood for identification

options.label: C
options.text: The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

questions.correct_answer: C. The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

questions.text: Which is the most important reason for preferring Letulle’s technique of autopsy in infants, particularly when congenital anomalies are suspected?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves removal of the brain first, which allows for better preservation of the cranial contents in cases of congenital abnormalities.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows opening the chest and abdominal cavities in sequence, which helps to better identify congenital anomalies, as compared to other techniques like Ghon's, Virchow's, or Rokitansky's.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves the dissection of the spinal cord first, which is particularly useful for detecting vertebral column abnormalities that may be present in infants with congenital malformations.

questions.correct_answer: B. It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It helps to preserve the relationship between the organs as they are found in situ, making it easier to identify anomalies in organ positioning or malformations without disturbing their natural anatomical arrangement.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with involuntary suspended animation? Electrocution Yoga Practitioners Drowning Burn
questions.correct_answer: B. 1 and 3

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of thyrotoxicosis is found dead in his home. The body temperature is 39°C measured 6 hours post-mortem, while the room temperature is 21°C. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the elevated body temperature after death?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis

options.label: B
options.text: Hypermetabolic state after death due to thyrotoxicosis

options.label: C
options.text: Early onset of rigor mortis caused by thyrotoxicosis, preventing cooling

questions.correct_answer: A. Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Hypermetabolic state before death due to thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: In which condition is an underwater autopsy of the heart primarily indicated to confirm diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Air embolism

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image?
questions.correct_answer: B. Odorless

questions.text: Which of the following best favours Adipocere formation:

options.label: A
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment

options.label: B
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, running water and anaerobic environment

options.label: C
options.text: Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and aerobic environment

options.label: D
options.text: Extremely high temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment

questions.correct_answer: A. Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water and anaerobic environment
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Moderately warm temperature, stagnant water, and anaerobic environment.

questions.text: A body is recovered from a river after few days of submersion. The body is found to be floating on the surface of the water. Which of the following is the most likely reason for this phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: The putrefaction process causes the accumulation of gases in the body, particularly in the abdomen, which leads to buoyancy and causes the body to float.

options.label: B
options.text: The body floats because of faster decomposition of the muscle tissue, leading to the body’s loss of density and buoyancy in water.

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of body fat in the individual allows the body to sink more rapidly, while the floating is likely due to external factors like water temperature or current.

questions.correct_answer: A. The putrefaction process causes the accumulation of gases in the body, particularly in the abdomen, which leads to buoyancy and causes the body to float.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The putrefaction process causes the accumulation of gases in the body, particularly in the abdomen, which leads to buoyancy and causes the body to float.

questions.text: A person dies due to antemortem drowning in a river, and after 2 days, the dead body is found floating in a body of water. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the floating of dead body?

options.label: A
options.text: Emphysema aquosum due to violent respiratory efforts made by the victim while getting drowned

options.label: B
options.text: Gases produced due to post-mortem bacterial decomposition activity reducing the body’s density and allowing it to float.

options.label: C
options.text: Rigor mortis causes muscle stiffening, making the body more rigid and causing it to float in the water.

questions.correct_answer: B. Gases produced due to post-mortem bacterial decomposition activity reducing the body’s density and allowing it to float.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Gases produced due to post-mortem bacterial decomposition activity reducing the body’s density and allowing it to float.

questions.text: "In forensic investigations, scab formation is an important indicator when estimating the age of an abrasion. Which of the following statements about scab formation in abrasions is correct in relation to the typical healing timeline?"

options.label: A
options.text: Scab formation typically begins two days after an abrasion, occurring due to increased pressure at the wound site.

options.label: B
options.text: Scab formation typically begins 12 hours after an abrasion, occurring due to rapid tissue necrosis.

options.label: C
options.text: The scab itself is primarily composed of dried serum and coagulated blood proteins, which act as a protective barrier.

options.label: D
options.text: The scab will remain intact and unchanged for several days, even if healing is progressing well beneath it.

questions.correct_answer: C. The scab itself is primarily composed of dried serum and coagulated blood proteins, which act as a protective barrier.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The scab itself is primarily composed of dried serum and coagulated blood proteins, which act as a protective barrier.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought by police for a medicolegal examination after being struck multiple times with a lathi during a strike. On examination, several injuries are noted. Which of the following injuries would not typically be caused by a lathi? Fissured fracture Abrasion collar Incised looking lacerated wound Incised wound

A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with multiple fractures in both lower limbs, specifically bumper fractures at the same level in each leg. The fractures are located just above the ankle joint and show evidence of bruising and contusions. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most important medico-legal consideration?

options.label: A
options.text: Bumper fractures at the same level in both legs suggest a deliberate attempt to injure both legs simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: A vehicle-pedestrian collision occurred, and the and the pedestrian was struck while in a stationary position, possibly not in motion.

options.label: C
options.text: Bumper fractures at the same level in both legs are most likely caused by a fall from a height.

options.label: D
options.text: The fractures being at the same level in both legs could indicate abuse or neglect in a child

questions.correct_answer: B. A vehicle-pedestrian collision occurred, and the and the pedestrian was struck while in a stationary position, possibly not in motion.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A vehicle-pedestrian collision occurred, and the and the pedestrian was struck while in a stationary position, possibly not in motion.

questions.text: In a case of alleged assault, the forensic expert is tasked with distinguishing between genuine and artificially produced injuries. Which substance is used for producing artificial bruises?
questions.correct_answer: B. Marking nut

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker suffers an eye injury after being struck by a metal fragment. He develops corneal opacity in the right eye. Following surgical intervention, his vision is restored. Medico-legally, how is this type of injury classified?
questions.correct_answer: A. Grievous

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to bomb blast injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshal’s triad occurs in secondary blast injuries and consists of multiple small abrasions, bruises and fractures

options.label: B
options.text: Primary blast injuries occur due to high velocity wind and causes injuries to gas filled internal organs like ear, lungs and intestines

options.label: C
options.text: Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries

options.label: D
options.text: Victim can be thrown away in tertiary blast injuries due to high pressure shock wave

questions.correct_answer: C. Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Primary blast injuries occur due to high pressure shock wave and does not cause external injuries

questions.text: What factor increases the risk of developing contrecoup injuries in a head impact?

options.label: D
options.text: Wearing a helmet at the time of impact

questions.correct_answer: A. Pre-existing brain atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding coup and contrecoup brain injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Brain contusion is the most common injury in both coup and contrecoup injuries.

options.label: B
options.text: Brain contusion is the most common injury in coup injuries, while brain lacerations are more common in contrecoup injuries.

options.label: C
options.text: Brain contusion occurs in coup injuries, but diffuse axonal injury is more likely in contrecoup injuries.

options.label: D
options.text: Brain contusion is the most common injury in coup injuries, while subdural hematomas are more common in contrecoup injuries.

questions.correct_answer: A. Brain contusion is the most common injury in both coup and contrecoup injuries.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Brain contusion is the most common injury in both coup and contrecoup injuries.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female was found dead at her home and an autopsy was performed to find the cause of death. Can you identify the probable cause of death from the image given below?
questions.correct_answer: C. Smothering

questions.text: Which of the following is False about gunshot wound?

options.label: A
options.text: Entry wound is usually smaller than exit wound

options.label: B
options.text: Contact shot on skull in entry wound have everted margins

options.label: C
options.text: Grease collar is present at exit wound

options.label: D
options.text: Rarely Abrasion collar may be seen in exit wound

questions.correct_answer: C. Grease collar is present at exit wound
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Grease collar is present at exit wound

questions.text: Why do entry wounds in contact shots to the skull typically have everted margins, while this is less common in other body parts?

options.label: A
options.text: The gunpowder residue burns the skin at the entry site, causing the skin to fold outward.

options.label: B
options.text: The hot propellant gases from the firearm are forced into the tissues of the skull, and the rigid nature of the skull amplifies the pressure, pushing the skin outward.

options.label: C
options.text: The impact of the bullet with the skull causes a shockwave that forces the skin to stretch outward.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain matter inside the skull explodes outward, creating a force that turns the skin around the entry wound outward.

questions.correct_answer: B. The hot propellant gases from the firearm are forced into the tissues of the skull, and the rigid nature of the skull amplifies the pressure, pushing the skin outward.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The hot propellant gases from the firearm are forced into the tissues of the skull, and the rigid nature of the skull amplifies the pressure, pushing the skin outward

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.correct_answer: B. Intermediate range

questions.text: ‘Paradox gun’ can fire?
questions.correct_answer: D. Both A and B

questions.text: Why is the dribbling of saliva considered a surest sign of antemortem hanging?

options.label: A
options.text: Dribbling of saliva indicates that the person was alive and conscious at the time of hanging, as the body retains the ability to produce and release saliva before death.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of saliva dribbling is indicative of a postmortem reflex action caused by the neck constriction during hanging.

options.label: C
options.text: Saliva dribbling occurs due to the natural postmortem relaxation of the muscles controlling the mouth, which happens during hanging.

questions.correct_answer: A. Dribbling of saliva indicates that the person was alive and conscious at the time of hanging, as the body retains the ability to produce and release saliva before death.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Dribbling of saliva indicates that the person was alive and conscious at the time of hanging, as the body retains the ability to produce and release saliva before death.

questions.text: All can cause traumatic asphyxia except:
questions.correct_answer: C. Accidental strangulation

questions.text: Which of the following would not typically occur during the lucid interval in an epidural hematoma?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient regains full consciousness and appears normal

options.label: B
options.text: The patient may experience confusion and disorientation

options.label: C
options.text: The patient’s neurological status improves temporarily

options.label: D
options.text: The hematoma is small and not yet causing significant pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient may experience confusion and disorientation
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The patient may experience confusion and disorientation

questions.text: Why is a lucid interval more commonly observed in cases of epidural hematoma (EDH) compared to subdural hematoma (SDH)?

options.label: A
options.text: EDH causes a slower, more gradual accumulation of blood, allowing time for the brain to compensate before symptoms worsen.

options.label: B
options.text: The location of bleeding in EDH is outside the dura, whereas in SDH, the bleeding occurs between the dura and the arachnoid membrane, leading to more immediate brain compression.

options.label: C
options.text: SDH is more likely to involve tearing of the brain's tissue, which leads to instant loss of consciousness and precludes a lucid interval.

options.label: D
options.text: Lucid intervals are a result of minor concussions, which are more common in EDH than in SDH

questions.correct_answer: B. The location of bleeding in EDH is outside the dura, whereas in SDH, the bleeding occurs between the dura and the arachnoid membrane, leading to more immediate brain compression.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The location of bleeding in EDH is outside the dura, whereas in SDH, the bleeding occurs between the dura and the arachnoid membrane, leading to more immediate brain compression.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "compos mentis" and mental illness is correct in the context of decision-making capacity?

options.label: A
options.text: A person with borderline personality disorder who exhibits emotional dysregulation but can still reason through a decision is not compos mentis.

options.label: B
options.text: A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.

options.label: C
options.text: A person diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder can never be considered compos mentis because they have multiple, distinct identities.

questions.correct_answer: B. A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A person with OCD who compulsively checks locks but understands the broader implications of their actions is compos mentis.

questions.text: A man is caught peeping into the bathroom of a girl’s hostel and trying to watch the female inhabitant’s bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.correct_answer: D. Voyeurism

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is involved in a custody dispute and undergoes a forensic evaluation to establish the paternity of her child. The forensic scientist plans to use a bodily fluid for ABO blood typing, as the child is suspected to have inherited the secretor status from the parents. Which of the following bodily fluids is least likely to be suitable for ABO blood group determination in secretors?
questions.correct_answer: D. Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
questions.correct_answer: D. Spectroscopic test

questions.text: In a complex legal case involving the dispute of inheritance rights, a person is accused of presenting a living child, who is not their own, as if the child were born to them, in an attempt to manipulate the legal proceedings. This act is being scrutinized by forensic experts and legal professionals to understand its implications and relevance to the case. What term best describes this act, particularly in the context of claiming inheritance rights?
questions.correct_answer: C. Suppositious Child

questions.text: A mother delivers twins, but one baby has much larger development as compared to other. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?
questions.correct_answer: B. Superfetation

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. Doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. It is suggestive of:
questions.correct_answer: B. Repeated anal sex with child
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Repeated anal sex with child

questions.text: A 35-year-old male construction worker is brought to hospital after experiencing nausea, dizziness, and weakness following several hours of heavy labor under the midday sun. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), heart rate is 110 beats per minute, BP is 105/60 mmHg, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. He appears pale and slightly diaphoretic. His laboratory studies show a mild electrolyte disturbance with low sodium (130 mmol/L). Likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Heat stroke with severe central nervous system dysfunction

options.label: B
options.text: Heat exhaustion with dehydration and electrolyte imbalance

options.label: C
options.text: Severe acute pancreatitis due to alcohol consumption

options.label: D
options.text: Hypertensive emergency precipitated by physical exertion

questions.correct_answer: B. Heat exhaustion with dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Heat exhaustion with dehydration and electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: A 42-year-old male construction worker is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at a worksite on a particularly hot afternoon. He appeared confused and irritable. His rectal temperature was recorded as 41.2°C (106.2°F). He is found to have rapid, shallow breathing. His pulse is 140 beats per minute, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute. Which of the following is Likely in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient is aware that he has a high body temperature.

questions.correct_answer: B. Patient can become unconscious

questions.text: True about the below image:

options.label: A
options.text: Heat stiffening due to ATP depletion

options.label: B
options.text: Protein coagulation due to heat stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.correct_answer: C. Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem burns

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?

options.label: C
options.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

questions.correct_answer: B. Joule burn is Hyperaemic

questions.text: Which of the following statements about frostbite is not true?

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of ice crystals within tissues

questions.correct_answer: C. Rewarming is not done

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features most strongly suggests Battered Baby Syndrome in an infant or young child, considering the typical patterns of abuse and diagnostic challenges?

options.label: A
options.text: A single rib fracture in a child who is crawling and has a history of a fall

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple rib fractures at various stages of healing in a non-ambulatory infant, with no reported trauma history

options.label: C
options.text: A single bruise on the forehead in an infant with a history of a minor bump against furniture

options.label: D
options.text: Frequent hospital visits for respiratory infections with no physical injuries noted on examination

questions.correct_answer: B. Multiple rib fractures at various stages of healing in a non-ambulatory infant, with no reported trauma history
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Multiple rib fractures at various stages of healing in a non-ambulatory infant, with no reported trauma history

questions.text: An 18-month-old female baby was referred for recurrent hypoglycemic attacks. Her first hypoglycemic attack occurred when she was 13 months old when her, mother, who is a hospital nurse, noticed lethargy, prolonged sleep and irritability. She was brough to hospital where blood sugar level was of 30 mg/dl. Since then such attacks have occurred 5 times, and she has been successfully managed with high dextrose (D25%), octreotide and glucagon. During all attacks her blood glucose is found to be low (about 20-40 mg / dl), and high insulin (3500-4000 pmol/L). During this hospital admission, one physician noticed needle marks on her both deltoids. The physician ordered C-peptide levels which was found to be almost negligible. Likely Diagnosis:
questions.correct_answer: A. Exogenous insulin administration to baby
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Exogenous insulin administration to baby

questions.text: The Spalding sign, characterized by the overlapping of cranial bones in a fetus after intrauterine death, is primarily caused by:

options.label: A
options.text: Severe maternal hypertension leading to intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)

options.label: B
options.text: Brain ischemia leading to intrauterine death

options.label: C
options.text: Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death, leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones

options.label: D
options.text: A genetic anomaly causing cranial bone malformation

questions.correct_answer: C. Shrinkage of the cerebrum after death, leading to loss of alignment and overriding of cranial bones

questions.text: In cyanide poisoning, cherry red discoloration of the skin is typically observed. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the cause of this distinctive skin color?

options.label: A
options.text: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome c oxidase, leading to impaired cellular respiration and retention of oxygenated hemoglobin in the blood.

options.label: B
options.text: Cyanide directly increases carbon monoxide production, leading to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which gives the skin a cherry red appearance.

options.label: C
options.text: The cyanide-cytochrome c oxidase complex is cherry red in colour.

options.label: D
options.text: Cyanide binds to hemoglobin, increasing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen and resulting in a bright red appearance due to high oxygen saturation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Cyanide inhibits cytochrome c oxidase, leading to impaired cellular respiration and retention of oxygenated hemoglobin in the blood.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Cyanide inhibits cytochrome c oxidase, leading to impaired cellular respiration and retention of oxygenated hemoglobin in the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which fomepizole prevents the toxic effects of ethylene glycol poisoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Fomepizole inhibits the enzyme responsible for converting glycolic acid to oxalic acid, directly preventing renal toxicity.

options.label: B
options.text: Fomepizole Non competitively inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), preventing the formation of toxic metabolites like glycolic acid and oxalic acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)

questions.correct_answer: C. Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Fomepizole has Higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)

questions.text: A botanist studying psychoactive plants collects a sample with white, large, trumpet-shaped flowers. What is the mechanism of action of this plant?

options.label: A
options.text: It act as acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, increasing acetylcholine levels in the synaptic cleft, leading to muscarinic receptor stimulation and sympathomimetic effects.

options.label: B
options.text: It act muscarinic receptor antagonists, blocking the effects of acetylcholine at the M1 and M2 receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: It is nicotinic receptor antagonists, inhibiting acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions, leading to skeletal muscle paralysis.

questions.correct_answer: B. It act muscarinic receptor antagonists, blocking the effects of acetylcholine at the M1 and M2 receptors.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It act muscarinic receptor antagonists, blocking the effects of acetylcholine at the M1 and M2 receptors.

questions.text: Identify which of the following statements are true regarding the materials required for forensic analysis of specific poisons: Vitreous humor is commonly examined for alcohol poisoning. The skin is analyzed for decomposition in cases of strychnine poisoning. Brain tissue is essential for detecting organophosphate poisoning. Fatty tissue is primarily used for examining pesticides and insecticides.
questions.correct_answer: B. Only 1, 3, and 4 are true

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below: Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gardener is found unresponsive after handling a plant as shown below. He is brought to the emergency department with bradycardia, hypotension, and severe arrhythmias. Despite treatment, he dies shortly after arrival. Which of the following plants is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: B. Aconite

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below and the condition it is responsible for:
questions.correct_answer: C. Ergot Poisoning

questions.text: If ingested, how do the seeds shown in the image typically affect a patient's level of consciousness?

options.label: B
options.text: Becomes unconscious in 1 hour or so

questions.correct_answer: D. Remains conscious throughout

questions.text: Both strychnine poisoning and tetanus can cause muscle spasms and rigidity, but the underlying mechanisms are different. What explains the mechanistic difference between strychnine and tetanus?

options.label: A
options.text: Strychnine causes postsynaptic inhibition of GABA, while tetanus toxin inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine at presynapse

options.label: B
options.text: Strychnine causes postsynaptic inhibition of glycine, while tetanus toxin inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine at presynapse

options.label: C
options.text: Strychnine causes postsynaptic inhibition of glycine while tetanus toxin interferes with the autonomic nervous system, causing vasoconstriction and muscle rigidity.

options.label: D
options.text: Strychnine inhibits acetylcholine release, whereas tetanus toxin enhances dopamine release, causing muscle spasms.

questions.correct_answer: B. Strychnine causes postsynaptic inhibition of glycine, while tetanus toxin inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine at presynapse
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Strychnine causes postsynaptic inhibition of glycine, while tetanus toxin inhibits the release of GABA and Glycine at presynapse

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to hospital with confusion, dizziness, and nausea, which began 6 hours after drinking a large amount of liquid from an unlabeled bottle she found in her garage. Vital signs: BP 120/75 mmHg, heart rate 105 bpm, respiratory rate 16/min. Lab results: Arterial pH: 7.30 (normal 7.35–7.45), pCO2: 28 mmHg (normal 35–45 mmHg), bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L (normal 22–28 mEq/L), anion gap: 18 mEq/L (normal 8–16 mEq/L), serum calcium: 7 mg/dL (normal 8.5–10.5 mg/dL). Likely cause?

options.label: D
options.text: Methanol toxicity with formic acid accumulation

questions.correct_answer: B. Oxalic acid-induced metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents to the emergency department after suspected exposure to a pesticide. He reports applying a pesticide to his crops 4 days earlier. Since 2 days he started feeling agitated and nervous, followed by tremors which increased gradually. Today he also had a seizure, and is bit confused. He has no signs of excessive salivation, diarrhea, or bradycardia. His vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate) are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Organochlorine poisoning

questions.text: A man at an airport was found in an agitated state and was shouting at passersby following which he suddenly collapsed. An Xray chest and abdomen showed the below picture. All of the following are true regarding this case except?

options.label: C
options.text: He is at a risk of intestinal obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: It’s a case of body packer’s syndrome

questions.correct_answer: B. The person is malingering

questions.text: A welder presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches after working with galvanized steel for several hours. The place of work is poorly ventillated. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, and there are no specific findings on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. Metal fume fever

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.correct_answer: D. Ethyl alcohol

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with symptoms of irritability, loss of appetite, and developmental delays. The child lives in an older building with possible lead-based paint exposure. The physician suspects lead poisoning and wants to confirm the diagnosis with laboratory testing. Which of the following biological samples is considered the most reliable for detecting lead poisoning?
questions.correct_answer: B. Blood

questions.text: Priapism occurs in which of the following conditions?
questions.correct_answer: C. Cantharide poisoning

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to hospital with confusion, vomiting, that began 10 hours after drinking a large quantity of homemade alcohol. The patient is disoriented and reports blurry vision. Vitals: BP 110/70 mmHg, heart rate 98 bpm, respiratory rate 14/min. Fundoscopic exam reveals bilateral papilledema. His Lab results are Arterial pH: 7.25 (normal 7.35–7.45), pCO2: 30 mmHg (normal 35-45 mmHg), Bicarbonate: 14 mEq/L (normal 22–28 mEq/L), Anion gap: 22 mEq/L (normal 8–16 mEq/L), and Blood glucose: 100 mg/dL. Likely cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Formic acid accumulation leading to high anion gap metabolic acidosis

options.label: B
options.text: Methanol poisoning leading to acute respiratory acidosis

options.label: C
options.text: Ethanol intoxication with secondary metabolic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Formic acid accumulation leading to high anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Formic acid accumulation leading to high anion gap metabolic acidosis
